title: Day 2
text:
Onboarding
I got settled at my desk and spent the day absorbing HydoTech pamphlets—learning about the company’s massive footprint in China and globally—and reading a detailed BCG report on the Hydrogen Energy Industry to get the “big picture” view.

title: Day 4
text:
Research Hurdle
Back at the office, the challenge ramped up. I was tasked with researching the stability of Nickel phases in an alkaline medium. This was a double-edged sword:

The Science: I’m new to electrochemistry, so the concepts were fresh.
The Toolset: I had to navigate the Chinese internet and Chinese AI tools.

I’m used to American web infrastructure, so suddenly not having my usual digital “crutches” made the learning curve steep. I spent the afternoon combing through references, line by line, paper by paper.

title: Day 3
text:
To the Factory
Vanessa, Yutong, Sia and I headed out to the factory. Seeing the manufacturing setup was very interesting; I walked through the areas where the electrolyzers are built and the R&D rooms where they undergo rigorous testing. One of the most unique sights? The Hydrogen Bicycle.

title: Day 3
text:
Team Building Games
HydoTech organized a massive game day for the workers, and I got thrown right into the mix. It was chaotic fun.

Galaibo: A classic game.
Ball Toss: Throwing and catching tennis balls as a squad.
The Counting Game: We had to count up as a team. (Proud to say I contributed by counting to four in Chinese!)
The Bamboo Run: Running across the road while holding onto a bamboo stick together.




Representation of One of the Games we Played


Despite winning the first event, our team lost overall. But the vibes were high.

title: Day 3
text:
Sweet Reward After
I then drove back to Nanjing with Sia and Yutong for a post-work treat: dumplings and milk tea at the mall. Sia introduced me to two different milk tea creations. Verdict: Delicious.

text: Research continued through the morning. At lunch, I hit a milestone: my first canteen noodles in China with Muyi. I had a delicious hot bowl of noodles with beef, perfect in the middle of a cold work day.

title: Day 5
text:
Electrical Schematics
In the afternoon, I shifted gears to something more comfortable to me: Electrical Engineering.
I reviewed the schematics for the CVM controller sent by Mr. Gu. I connected the dots between the schematics and the system overview Mr. Gu had shown me earlier. To wrap up the day, I took the metro home—I always think public transport is the best way to learn the heartbeat of a new city.

title: Day 6
text:
Stop 1: The R&D Field Station
We saw a testbench for a big electrolyzer that the clients wanted Mr. Gu to take a look at. It’s quite a machine, consuming CO2 and recycling its own heat. Seeing technology with that kind of prospect for the future was inspiring.

title: Day 6
text:
Stop 2: Manufacturing
We toured the assembly lines (a mix of full and partial automation) where they seal the controller PCBs. We walked through the vibration and environmental testing rooms—rigorous stuff.

title: Day 6
text:
The CVM Test
Finally, we got our hands on the HydoTech CVM controller system I had studied the day before. Here is how the system flow worked:

Distribution: Test voltage leads to probes connecting to the electrolyzer substrate.
Conversion: Inside the controller, voltage is converted to a two-byte representation and biased upward (to avoid negatives).
Transmission: Transmission: Data is sent via two CAN ports \(\rightarrow\) CAN-to-Ethernet gateway \(\rightarrow\) Modbus conversion \(\rightarrow\) Gateway.
Cloud: Over the router, data goes via 5G to the server.

We validated the real-time data on the computer using a multimeter.



Probing the CVM Controller with a Multimeter

title: Day 6
text:
Panda Cake and Japanese
We returned to Nanjing for a dinner with the whole crew: Yutong, Yubo, Mr. Gu, Muyi, and Vanessa. Great company and excellent food, headlined by a green cake featuring edible pandas. The Japanese food served for dinner was also really great.

title: Day 7
text:
Further Research
I continued my research into the phases of Nickel at 30 wt% KOH. I found different papers that took different approaches of experimentation to characterize the phases. Some were contradictory, leading me to look deeper into the conditions under which the experiments took place. I first looked into the different types of experimentation, to better understand what data was exactly being extracted- what exactly was being measured and by what means. These included Raman Spectroscopies, Cyclic Voltammetries, Pourbaix Diagrams, and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopies. Once I had a better idea, I began writing down the different experimental conditions.

Dinner
For dinner, Sia, Yutong, and two of Sia’s friends and I went to Haidilao for Hotpot. I got my nails done, which comes as a package of getting the food. I tried many new different foods, including: Duck brain, duck blood, chicken feet, and cow intestine. I really liked the cow intestine. We had the tomato sauce and the Chongqing spicy sauce, which I actually found quite bearable.
